The Greeks hold various views about this plant; some under the same name speak of a dark plant xw'th leaves like those of the pine, assuring us that, so wonderful is its nature, its mere touch stanches a patient’s bleedingg some call it hippuris, others ephedron, others anabasis. Their account is that it grows near trees, which it climbs, and hangs down in many dark, rusb-like hairs as if from a horse's tail; that its little branches are jointed, and its leaves few, slenderb and small3 that the seed is round, resembling that of coriander, that its root is ligneous, and that it grows mostly in plantations.
